Award.AwardTitle: Amenabilty, soficity, dynamics, and operator algebras
Award.AbstractNarration:
The subject of functional analysis provides a powerful mathematical language for the investigation of infinite-dimensional structures. The abstract nature of this language allows for a wide spectrum of applications, whose various settings include quantum mechanics, the theory of probability, and the study of systems, physical or otherwise, as they evolve in time. The project will concentrate on several aspects and generalized forms of the last of these three settings, and it will largely revolve around phenomena related to entropy.

Finite or finite-dimensional approximation has long played a fundamental role in both dynamics and operator algebras and is manifest in its most basic and influential forms through the notions of amenability and soficity and their algebraic analogues. In the domain of C*-algebras, amenability has been subject to various refinements like finite decomposition rank and finite nuclear dimension that express the kind of topological regularity necessary for K-theoretic classification theorems within the Elliott program. This project aims to broaden our understanding of the relationships between these regularity properties and phenomena in topological dynamics, in particular mean dimension and Rokhlin-type dimensional invariants, and to test this understanding on a variety of examples that have so far remained beyond the scope of classification, such as actions of branch groups. Combinatorial independence will be brought into this picture as a tool for analyzing mixing and paradoxicality in dynamics and their relation to quasidiagonality and dimensional behavior, and it will be also applied to actions of sofic groups in the study of entropy and orbit equivalence.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project has contributed to a longstanding program to investigate randomness, symmetry, paradoxicality, and dimensionality in dynamical systems. It has aimed to understand the way in which combinatorial, geometric, and topological phenomena interrelate within the wider scope in dynamics that has been opened up by recent advances in entropy theory, the theory of infinite groups, and the classification program for nuclear C*-algebras. A major theme has been the development of a dynamical analogue of the Toms-Winter conjecture in C*-algebra theory, including generalized notions of dynamical comparison and almost finiteness, and the application of these ideas to significantly enlarge the range of C*-crossed products known to fall under the purview of classification theory. In another direction, a novel spectral approach was developed to establish a Bekka-Valette-type characterization of property (T) in the context of locally compact quantum groups.


Part of the project has involved the completion of a book on ergodic theory with Hanfeng Li which is intended to serve both as an introduction for graduate students and as a general reference for researchers in the field. The book also includes a comprehensive treatment of various topics of current interest based around the themes of dichotomies and independence.


The results of the project were disseminated in a variety of national and international venues, including Institute of Mathematical Sciences in Madrid (June 2019), the Institute for Pure and Applied Mathematics at UCLA (May 2018), the Henri Poincare Institute in Paris (July 2017), the Banff International Research Station in Canada (July 2017), the Mathematisches Forschungsinstitut Oberwolfach in Germany (September 2017 and August 2016), the Abel Symposium in Norway (August 2016), the Erwin Schroedinger Institute in Vienna (February 2016), the Mittag-Leffler Institute in Sweden (February and March 2016), and the Centre de Recherches Mathematiques in Montreal (June 2016).
